<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> clusters was used as a synthetic route to one-dimensional magnetic material. Comparison of the magnetic properties of the building block cluster and the 1D material revealed that they both exhibit SMM behavior with no evidence of intermolecular interactions within the chain.<ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The polymerization of MnIII 6 clusters was used as a synthetic route to one-dimensional magnetic material. Comparison of the magnetic properties of the building block cluster and the 1D material revealed that they both exhibit SMM behavior with no evidence of intermolecular interactions within the chain.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The 1D coordination polymer [MnIII 6O2(O2CC6H4CO2)(salox)6(dmf)4] n ⋅2n(dmf) (2⋅2n(dmf)) was obtained from the reaction of [MnIII 6O2(O2CPh)2(salox)6(Me2CO)2(H2O)2]⋅2Me2CO (1⋅2Me2CO) with excess of terephthalic acid in MeCN/dmf. The structure of 2 consists of [MnIII 6O2(salox)6(dmf)4]2+ units bridged through the terephthalato dianions. The Mn6 units present the [Mn6(μ 3-O)2(μ 2-OR)2]12+ core and can be described as two [Mn3(μ 3-O)]7+ triangular subunits linked by two μ2-oximato oxygen atoms of the salox2- ligands, which show the μ3-κ2 O:κO':κN coordination mode. Each carboxylato group of the terephthalato dianion is coordinated through the usual syn,syn μ2-κO:κO' coordination mode. Both 2 and 1 contain the same [Mn6(μ 3-O)2(μ 2-OR)2]12+ core, and the replacement of the two benzoates in 1 from the terephthalato dianion generates the 1D structure in 2. The dynamic magnetic properties of both compounds were monitored by alternating current magnetic susceptibility measurements. Both complexes exhibit Single Molecule Magnet behavior with no evidence for inter-cluster magnetic interactions for 2. For complex 1 an unusually broad distribution of relaxation times was observed.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Molecular magnetic materials have gained great interest because of their nanometer size which lies in between the macroscopic and mesoscopic regime, and most importantly because they represent the real objects in which quantum phenomena were observed . An important sub-class of these materials are the so-called Single-Molecule Magnets (SMMs) i.e. polynuclear metal complexes whose special magnetic properties arise from the combination of a large spin (S) and an Ising (easy-axis) magneto-anisotropy, thus exhibiting a negative zero-field splitting parameter (D), which gives rise to the superparamagnetic-like property of a barrier to magnetization relaxation. During the last two decades, numerous efforts and synthetic techniques gave rise to SMMs with nuclearities ranging up to 84 metal ions . On the other hand, an equally important sub-class of molecular magnetic materials are the so-called Single-Chain Magnets (SCMs) i.e. magnetically active infinite coordination polymers whose slow relaxation of magnetization is not solely the consequence of a high-spin ground state and the uniaxial anisotropy seen by each spin along the chain, but also depends on magnetic correlations. An important feature for the observation of single-chain magnetism behavior is that the chains must be magnetically isolated as much as possible in order to avoid 3D ordering. The occurrence of slow relaxation and Arrhenius behavior of the relaxation time in one-dimensional systems was predicted theoretically by Glauber using a 1D Ising model ; however the first evidence of such behavior was reported only in 2001 . To date, several kinds of SCMs have been realized by the assembly of spin-carriers bridged by nitronyl nitroxides , azides , Prussian blue anions and derivates , acetates , and metal pyridine-2-aldoximate complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Molecular magnetic materials have gained great interest because of their nanometer size which lies in between the macroscopic and mesoscopic regime, and most importantly because they represent the real objects in which quantum phenomena were observed . An important sub-class of these materials are the so-called Single-Molecule Magnets (SMMs) i.e. polynuclear metal complexes whose special magnetic properties arise from the combination of a large spin (S) and an Ising (easy-axis) magneto-anisotropy, thus exhibiting a negative zero-field splitting parameter (D), which gives rise to the superparamagnetic-like property of a barrier to magnetization relaxation. During the last two decades, numerous efforts and synthetic techniques gave rise to SMMs with nuclearities ranging up to 84 metal ions . On the other hand, an equally important sub-class of molecular magnetic materials are the so-called Single-Chain Magnets (SCMs) i.e. magnetically active infinite coordination polymers whose slow relaxation of magnetization is not solely the consequence of a high-spin ground state and the uniaxial anisotropy seen by each spin along the chain, but also depends on magnetic correlations. An important feature for the observation of single-chain magnetism behavior is that the chains must be magnetically isolated as much as possible in order to avoid 3D ordering. The occurrence of slow relaxation and Arrhenius behavior of the relaxation time in one-dimensional systems was predicted theoretically by Glauber using a 1D Ising model ; however the first evidence of such behavior was reported only in 2001 . To date, several kinds of SCMs have been realized by the assembly of spin-carriers bridged by nitronyl nitroxides , azides , Prussian blue anions and derivates , acetates , and metal pyridine-2-aldoximate complexes .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">From the synthetic chemist point of view, the synthesis of SMMs by design is a great challenge and as experience was gained by employing self-assembly methods , led to the development of synthetic methodologies, such as chemical modifications of preformed clusters, proper choice of polydentate ligands, and use of oligonuclear building blocks . Ligand exchange interactions in preformed clusters were proved fruitful tools in inducing structural modification and/or distortion and thus promoting fine tuning of the magnetic properties or introducing desired magnetic behavior, such as single molecule magnetism . Moving one step further, metal clusters – preferably showing SMM behavior – were used as building blocks to design new magnetic nano-objects or networks. This approach offered the possibility to control the magnitude of the inter-SMM magnetic interactions and thus border the gap between SMMs and bulk classical magnets. Indeed, this area of research has been proved very fruitful to design chains as well as 2D and 3D arrays based on SMM building blocks connected through covalent and supermolecular bonds . In that respect, we have previously reported Fe<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> carboxylato complexes of salicylaldehyde oxime (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>salox) which form 1D chains and 2D networks through intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions in the crystal lattice , as well as analogous Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> complexes assembled into 1D chains through coordination between the [Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] moiety and intervening Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions . To continue our work in a more rational manner, we have attempted to link discrete oligonuclear clusters with suitable bridging organic ligands to prepare new 1D-3D materials. We present herein, the synthesis of a 1D coordination polymer, [Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(salox)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>·2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>(dmf), which is based on preformed Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> building units assembled via coordinated terephthalato ligands. We also present the magnetic study of the 1D material and compare its properties with those of the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> building units.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From the synthetic chemist point of view, the synthesis of SMMs by design is a great challenge and as experience was gained by employing self-assembly methods , led to the development of synthetic methodologies, such as chemical modifications of preformed clusters, proper choice of polydentate ligands, and use of oligonuclear building blocks . Ligand exchange interactions in preformed clusters were proved fruitful tools in inducing structural modification and/or distortion and thus promoting fine tuning of the magnetic properties or introducing desired magnetic behavior, such as single molecule magnetism . Moving one step further, metal clusters - preferably showing SMM behavior - were used as building blocks to design new magnetic nano-objects or networks. This approach offered the possibility to control the magnitude of the inter-SMM magnetic interactions and thus border the gap between SMMs and bulk classical magnets. Indeed, this area of research has been proved very fruitful to design chains as well as 2D and 3D arrays based on SMM building blocks connected through covalent and supermolecular bonds . In that respect, we have previously reported FeIII 3 and FeIII 6 carboxylato complexes of salicylaldehyde oxime (H2salox) which form 1D chains and 2D networks through intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions in the crystal lattice , as well as analogous MnIII 3 complexes assembled into 1D chains through coordination between the [MnIII 3] moiety and intervening Na+ ions . To continue our work in a more rational manner, we have attempted to link discrete oligonuclear clusters with suitable bridging organic ligands to prepare new 1D-3D materials. We present herein, the synthesis of a 1D coordination polymer, [MnIII 6O2(O2CC6H4CO2)(salox)6(dmf)4] n ⋅2n(dmf), which is based on preformed MnIII 6 building units assembled via coordinated terephthalato ligands. We also present the magnetic study of the 1D material and compare its properties with those of the MnIII 6 building units.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General and spectroscopic measurements

All manipulations were performed under aerobic conditions using materials as received (Aldrich Co). All chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade. [MnIII 6O2(O2CPh)2(salox)6(Me2CO)2(H2O)2]⋅2Me2CO (1⋅2Me2CO) was synthesized as previously described . Elemental analysis for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen was performed on a Perkin Elmer 2400/II automatic analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets in the range 4000-400cm-1 on a Bruker Equinox 55/S FT-IR spectrophotometer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 using a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID susceptometer. DC data were collected in the 2-300K temperature range under magnetic fields of 0.1T for 1 and 0.5 T for 2. Alternating Current (ac) magnetic susceptibility experiments were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS magnetometer. AC data for 1 and 2 were collected between 2-7K, with an oscillating field of 2-5G amplitude and 10-10000Hz frequencies. Diamagnetic corrections for the complexes were estimated from Pascal's constants.

Compound preparation

[MnIII 6O2(O2CC6H4CO2)(salox)6(dmf)4]n⋅2n(dmf) (2⋅2n(dmf))

A colorless solution of terephthalic acid (0.032g, 0.192mmol) in dmf (14ml) was added to a dark brown solution of [Mn6O2(O2CPh)2(salox)6(Me2CO)2(H2O)2] (1) (0.075g, 0.048mmol) in MeCN (18ml). The resulting dark green-brown solution was stirred with gentle heating for 15min and filtered off to obtain a clear dark green-brown solution. Layer of Et2O to the final reaction solution afforded brown prismatic crystals of 2⋅2n(dmf) after one week. Yield: 0.030 gr, ~34%. The crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3466sb, 3243wsh, 3060w, 3011w, 2927w, 1658msh, 1646vs, 1598s, 1587wsh, 1560s, 1544ssh, 1500w, 1471m, 1440s, 1413w, 1382vs, 1324w, 1284m, 1255w, 1202m, 1151m, 1124w, 1104m, 1044m, 1029s, 1004wsh, 962w, 915s, 860w, 820m, 755s, 675s, 646m, 549w, 531mb, 478m, 466m. Anal. Calc. for C68H76Mn6N12O24 (1775.05): C, 46.01; H, 4.32; N, 9.47. Found: C, 45.82; H, 4.35; N, 9.42%.

elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray crystallography

A brown crystal of 2⋅2n(dmf) (0.05×0.15×0.19mm) was taken directly from the mother liquor and immediately cooled to -93°C. Diffraction measurements were made on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER Image Plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation. Data collection (ω-scans) and processing (cell refinement, data reduction and Empirical absorption correction) were performed using the CrystalClear program package . The structure was solved by direct methods using Shelxs-97  and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 with Shelxl-97 . Important crystallographic data are listed in  . Further experimental crystallographic details for 2⋅2n(dmf): 2θ max =130°; reflections collected/unique/used, 17660/6037 [R int =0.0552]/6037; 509 parameters refined; (Δ/σ)max =0.001; (Δρ)max/(Δρ)min =0.610/-0.671e/Å3; R/R w (for all data), 0.0707/0.1581. Hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions as riding on bonded atoms. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The oxygen atom of the solvate dmf molecule was found disordered and was refined over two positions with occupation factors fixed at 0.50. Plots of the structures were drawn using the Diamond 3 program package .

<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(salox)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>

</ce:italic>·2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>(dmf) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>(dmf)). The synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>(dmf) involves the polymerization of a predesigned secondary building unit, i.e. [Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(salox)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·2Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO). Excess of terephthalic acid was used to ensure full replacement of the benzoate ligands. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was chosen as a building unit because it belongs to a family of complexes displaying SMM behavior which were extensively studied by Perlepes–Brechin and co-workers. They showed that the targeted structural distortion through the introduction of bulk substituents on the ligands invokes a dramatic change in the observed magnetic properties by switching weak antiferromagnetic exchange to weak ferromagnetic exchange . From the structural point of view, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains terminally bound benzoates and solvent molecules which can be replaced by analogous ligands, thus rendering it an excellent building unit for the synthesis of new materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

The reaction of [MnIII 6O2(O2CPh)2(salox)6(Me2CO)2(H2O)2]⋅2Me2CO (1⋅2Me2CO) , with excess of terephthalic acid in MeCN/dmf afforded a green-brown solution which upon layering of Et2O afforded X-ray quality crystals of [MnIII 6O2(O2CC6H4CO2)(salox)6(dmf)4] n ⋅2n(dmf) (2⋅2n(dmf)). The synthesis of 2⋅2n(dmf) involves the polymerization of a predesigned secondary building unit, i.e. [MnIII 6O2(O2CPh)2(salox)6(Me2CO)2(H2O)2]⋅2Me2CO (1⋅2Me2CO). Excess of terephthalic acid was used to ensure full replacement of the benzoate ligands. Complex 1 was chosen as a building unit because it belongs to a family of complexes displaying SMM behavior which were extensively studied by Perlepes-Brechin and co-workers. They showed that the targeted structural distortion through the introduction of bulk substituents on the ligands invokes a dramatic change in the observed magnetic properties by switching weak antiferromagnetic exchange to weak ferromagnetic exchange . From the structural point of view, complex 1 contains terminally bound benzoates and solvent molecules which can be replaced by analogous ligands, thus rendering it an excellent building unit for the synthesis of new materials.

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Analogous 1D coordination polymers based on Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> SMMs units linked through dicarboxylato ligands have been reported earlier. Their synthesis was achieved by a different synthetic methodology based on the self-assembly approach, by the reaction of Mn(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Rsalox and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L (R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Et, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>iso-phthalate(-2), succinate(-2); R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>terephthalate(-2); R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Et, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bithio-phenedicarboxylato(-2)) in basic alcoholic solutions . Similarly, the reaction of Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, 4-MeO-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>salox and NaN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in basic methanolic solutions afforded [Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-MeO-salox)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] units doubly linked by azide anions . Our attempts to prepare <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> according to the above synthetic methodology from dmf and mixed MeCN/dmf solutions led to a completely different crystalline material .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Analogous 1D coordination polymers based on MnIII 6 SMMs units linked through dicarboxylato ligands have been reported earlier. Their synthesis was achieved by a different synthetic methodology based on the self-assembly approach, by the reaction of Mn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, H2Rsalox and Na2L (R=Et, L=iso-phthalate(-2), succinate(-2); R=NH2, L=terephthalate(-2); R=Et, L=bithio-phenedicarboxylato(-2)) in basic alcoholic solutions . Similarly, the reaction of Mn(NO3)2⋅4H2O, 4-MeO-H2salox and NaN3 in basic methanolic solutions afforded [MnIII 6O2(4-MeO-salox)6(MeOH)4] units doubly linked by azide anions . Our attempts to prepare 2 according to the above synthetic methodology from dmf and mixed MeCN/dmf solutions led to a completely different crystalline material .

<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) bands are observed in the range 1580–1560 and 1400–1360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the IR spectrum of 2 medium-intensity bands at 3060 and 2927cm-1 are assigned to the ν(CH)aromatic and ν(CH3) stretching vibrations, respectively. A strong intensity band at 1598cm-1 and a medium intensity band at 1284cm-1 are assigned to the ν(CN) and ν(N-Oox) of the salicylaldoximato ligand, respectively . The strong absorption bands at 1560 and 1382cm-1 are attributed to the ν as(CO2) and ν s(CO2) bands of the terephthalato dianion, respectively; the assignment is based on literature data of the corresponding dipotassium, disodium and disilver salts and analogous terephthlato complexes . In all cases, the ν as(CO2) and ν s(CO2) bands are observed in the range 1580-1560 and 1400-1360cm-1, respectively.

elements.clean_text:
Description of the structure

Compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . The asymmetric unit contains half terephthalato dianion, one trinuclear [MnIII 3O(salox)3(dmf)2] unit and one dmf solvate molecule. The terephthalato dianion resides on an inversion centre at (0, 1, 0) and links two symmetry related [MnIII 3O(salox)3(dmf)2] units, each of which resides on an inversion centre at (0.5, 0.5, 0), thus generating the hexanuclear building units [MnIII 6O2(salox)6(dmf)4]2+ of the polymer (  ). The so-formed 1D chain extends along the (110) crystallographic plane. Neighboring chains in the crystal lattice run parallel to each other without interacting due to the absence of considerable intermolecular interactions (). The Mn6 units contain a [Mn6(μ 3-O)2(μ 2-OR)2]12+ core, consisting of six manganese(III) ions arranged as two inversion-related off-set stacked [Mn3(μ 3-O)]7+ subunits bridged by two oximato oxygen atoms (O(22) and O(22')). In each [Mn3(μ 3-O)]7+ subunit, there are two Mn⋯Mn pairs [Mn(1)/Mn(2) and Mn(2)/Mn3)] bridged by a μ2 oxide and a μ2-κO:κO':κN salox2- ligand, while the third pair [Mn(1)/Mn(3)] is further bridged by a μ2 carboxylato group of the terephthalato ligand. Two of the salox2- ligands in each [Mn3(μ 3-O)]7+ subunit adopt the μ2:κO:κO':κN coordination mode, and the third exhibits the μ3:κ2 O:κO':κN coordination mode ( ), that has been also observed in 1 , and analogous hexanuclear  as well as trinuclear and tetranuclear complexes . These, along with the central μ 3-O2- ion and the syn, syn μ2-κO:κO' carboxylates of the terephthalato dianion promote distorted octahedral coordination geometry around Mn(1) and Mn(2), and square pyramidal coordination environment around Mn(3) ions.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic studies

DC magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out on polycrystalline samples of both 1 and 2 in the 2-300K range. The results are plotted in the form of χT versus T and are shown in  . The χT product of 1 at 300K is 18.4cm3 mol-1 K. This decreases upon cooling, reaching a value of 6.75cm3 mol-1 K at 2K. The χT product of 2 at 300K is 17.55cm3 mol-1 K. Upon cooling, χT decreases to a value of 11.78cm3 mol-1 K at 20K. Below 8.5K χT decreases abruptly reaching a value of 8.17cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0K. For both complexes the χT is comparable with the theoretically expected value for six non-interacting S =2 spins (18.00cm3 mol-1 K, g =2.0). The temperature dependence of χT suggests dominant antiferromagnetic intra-molecular interactions. The expected value for χT for an S =4 system is 10.0cm3 mol-1 K. The values of χT at 2K for 1 and 2 are smaller than this value and this could be due to zero field splitting effects and/or to the influence of low lying states. The magnetization isotherms for both complexes at 2K do not reach saturation up to a magnetic field of 8.5T indicating contributions from low lying excited states and/or intermolecular interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Brechin and coworkers have shown  that the dihedral Mn–O–N–Mn angles within the Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangles correlate strongly with the sign and size of the respective Mn–Mn magnetic couplings. In particular, they derived that below a value of ∼30.4°, the interaction is antiferromagnetic, while above 31.3° it switches to ferromagnetic. The nature of the magnetic interactions on these structural characteristics has a direct consequence to the total spin of the ground state, and clusters with ground spin of <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 up to <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12 have been synthesized. The dihedral angles were determined to be 1.13, 21.63 and 24.50° in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 15.58, 39.48 and 19.98° in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. These values suggest that the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> belong to the clusters of the Mn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> family with low spin ground states. The differences in the values for these geometrical elements may account for the different behavior of the <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>M</ce:italic> versus <ce:italic>H</ce:italic> data.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Brechin and coworkers have shown  that the dihedral Mn-O-N-Mn angles within the Mn3 triangles correlate strongly with the sign and size of the respective Mn-Mn magnetic couplings. In particular, they derived that below a value of ~30.4°, the interaction is antiferromagnetic, while above 31.3° it switches to ferromagnetic. The nature of the magnetic interactions on these structural characteristics has a direct consequence to the total spin of the ground state, and clusters with ground spin of S =4 up to S =12 have been synthesized. The dihedral angles were determined to be 1.13, 21.63 and 24.50° in 1 and 15.58, 39.48 and 19.98° in 2. These values suggest that the 1 and 2 belong to the clusters of the Mn6 family with low spin ground states. The differences in the values for these geometrical elements may account for the different behavior of the M versus T and M versus H data.

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The dynamic magnetic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were studied in a comparative manner, in order to examine eventual differences arising between the 0D and the 1D materials.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Variable-temperature and variable-frequency ac susceptibility studies for both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected between 2–7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at various frequencies between 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz and 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kHz. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>) the presence of out-of-phase signals, characteristic of slow magnetic relaxation is attributed to single-molecule magnetism. AC susceptibility data for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>) also revealed clear peaks in the out-of-phase susceptibility (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>″) and decreases in the in-phase susceptibility (<ce:italic>χ′</ce:italic>) indicating slow magnetization relaxation in this temperature and frequency range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The dynamic magnetic properties of 1 and 2 were studied in a comparative manner, in order to examine eventual differences arising between the 0D and the 1D materials.

Variable-temperature and variable-frequency ac susceptibility studies for both 1 and 2 were collected between 2-7K at various frequencies between 10Hz and 10kHz. For 1 ( ) the presence of out-of-phase signals, characteristic of slow magnetic relaxation is attributed to single-molecule magnetism. AC susceptibility data for 2 ( ) also revealed clear peaks in the out-of-phase susceptibility (χ") and decreases in the in-phase susceptibility (χ') indicating slow magnetization relaxation in this temperature and frequency range.

elements.clean_text: The ac susceptibility data were analyzed within the generalized Debye model . The complex susceptibility is given by:  (1)  χ =   χ   S   +     χ   T   -   χ   S     1 + ( i ω τ   )   1 - α       where χT  and χS  are the susceptibilities at zero and infinite frequency, respectively, ω is the excitation frequency, τ is the relaxation time and α is a parameter between 0 and 1 which relates to the distribution of relaxation times. For a narrow distribution of the relaxation times α →0 whereas α →1 for an infinitely broad distribution. This parameter can be determined by analyzing χ" versus χ' plots (Cole-Cole plots) on the basis of Eq. (1) . Such plots, for two representative temperatures are shown in  . For comparison purposes we show also the resulting curves by keeping α =0 in the fitting procedure.

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">In

This behavior is common in Single Molecule Magnets  as well as in other polynuclear transition metal clusters . For typical paramagnets <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.3  and this is the case for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in the whole temperature range. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, however, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.45 reaching a value of 0.65 at the lowest temperature. Such large values are generally considered as an indication for spin glass behavior .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In   we show the temperature dependency of α. For both complexes, α increases as the temperature decreases. This behavior is common in Single Molecule Magnets  as well as in other polynuclear transition metal clusters . For typical paramagnets α <0.3  and this is the case for 2 in the whole temperature range. For 1, however, α >0.45 reaching a value of 0.65 at the lowest temperature. Such large values are generally considered as an indication for spin glass behavior .

elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of τ, in the form ln τ versus 1/T for both complexes is shown in  . For complex 1 a linear dependence is observed suggesting that relaxation follows an Arrhenius-type law, with the characteristic time τ at temperature T given by τ = τ 0⋅eΔ  E  /  kT . Fitting of the data yields a relaxation barrier ΔE of 23 (±2)K (16±1cm-1) with a pre-exponential factor τ 0 of 1.6 (±0.2)×10-8 s. For complex 2, a linear dependence is also observed for T >3.0K and fitting to the Arrhenius law yields ΔE =29 (±2)K (20±1cm-1) and τ 0 =2.7 (±0.2)×10-8 s. Below 3.0K a deviation from linearity is observed. This is often observed in SMMs and is attributed to the onset of quantum tunneling mechanisms for the relaxation.

The large value for α is attributed to broad distributions in the relaxation times. Such broad distributions may due to the influence of low lying excited states and/or to distributions on the energy barrier.</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Finally, we observe that the value of parameter <ce:italic>α</ce:italic> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is much smaller than this of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicating narrower distributions of the relaxation times for the former. This may be attributed to different influence of low lying excited states as a result of differences in the mapping of the spin manifolds in the two compounds and/or different distributions on the energy barrier.</ce:para>

This may be attributed to different influence of low lying excited states as a result of differences in the mapping of the spin manifolds in the two compounds and/or different distributions on the energy barrier.

<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">Since the first report of Perlepes and coworkers, the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> motif has been proven extremely versatile resulting to a family of SMMs. Subtle differences on the magnetic exchange interactions lead to different magnetic properties reflected in the variety of the values of the spin of the ground state ranging from <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 to <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12. Recently, the possibility for using Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> clusters in order to construct one-dimensional magnets (SCMs) has been explored. Their synthesis was achieved by employing self-assembly routes by the use of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts, salicylaldehyde oxime and/or its derivatives and the proper dicarboxylato ligand. In the present work we have followed a different synthetic route that enables polymerization of the preformed Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> clusters by replacing the terminally bound carboxylates with bridging dicarboxylates. Our results are in agreement with the observed structural stability of the [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-OR)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">12+</ce:sup> core and further confirm that these Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> clusters are susceptible to replacement of the auxiliary carboxylato ligands, thus constitute excellent building blocks for the synthesis of pre-designed magnetic materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Since the first report of Perlepes and coworkers, the MnIII 6 motif has been proven extremely versatile resulting to a family of SMMs. Subtle differences on the magnetic exchange interactions lead to different magnetic properties reflected in the variety of the values of the spin of the ground state ranging from S =4 to S =12. Recently, the possibility for using MnIII 6 clusters in order to construct one-dimensional magnets (SCMs) has been explored. Their synthesis was achieved by employing self-assembly routes by the use of MnII salts, salicylaldehyde oxime and/or its derivatives and the proper dicarboxylato ligand. In the present work we have followed a different synthetic route that enables polymerization of the preformed MnIII 6 clusters by replacing the terminally bound carboxylates with bridging dicarboxylates. Our results are in agreement with the observed structural stability of the [Mn6(μ 3-O)2(μ 2-OR)2]12+ core and further confirm that these MnIII 6 clusters are susceptible to replacement of the auxiliary carboxylato ligands, thus constitute excellent building blocks for the synthesis of pre-designed magnetic materials.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">Magnetic studies indicate that clusters <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> belong to the “low- spin” class of the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> family in agreement with magneto-structural correlations on the basis of the dihedral Mn–O–N–Mn angles within the Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> triangles. AC magnetic susceptibility studies reveal that both clusters exhibit SMM behavior. Although in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> arrange in a one dimensional array no evidence for SCM behavior was observed. Analysis of Cole–cole plots revealed that the relaxation time for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibit large distributions which is rather unusual for SMMs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Magnetic studies indicate that clusters 1 and 2 belong to the "low- spin" class of the MnIII 6 family in agreement with magneto-structural correlations on the basis of the dihedral Mn-O-N-Mn angles within the Mn3 triangles. AC magnetic susceptibility studies reveal that both clusters exhibit SMM behavior. Although in 2 the MnIII 6 arrange in a one dimensional array no evidence for SCM behavior was observed. Analysis of Cole-cole plots revealed that the relaxation time for 1 exhibit large distributions which is rather unusual for SMMs.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Compound preparation

[MnIII 6O2(O2CC6H4CO2)(salox)6(dmf)4]n⋅2n(dmf) (2⋅2n(dmf))

A colorless solution of terephthalic acid (0.032g, 0.192mmol) in dmf (14ml) was added to a dark brown solution of [Mn6O2(O2CPh)2(salox)6(Me2CO)2(H2O)2] (1) (0.075g, 0.048mmol) in MeCN (18ml). The resulting dark green-brown solution was stirred with gentle heating for 15min and filtered off to obtain a clear dark green-brown solution. Layer of Et2O to the final reaction solution afforded brown prismatic crystals of 2⋅2n(dmf) after one week. Yield: 0.030 gr, ~34%. The crystals were collected by filtration and dried in air. FT-IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3466sb, 3243wsh, 3060w, 3011w, 2927w, 1658msh, 1646vs, 1598s, 1587wsh, 1560s, 1544ssh, 1500w, 1471m, 1440s, 1413w, 1382vs, 1324w, 1284m, 1255w, 1202m, 1151m, 1124w, 1104m, 1044m, 1029s, 1004wsh, 962w, 915s, 860w, 820m, 755s, 675s, 646m, 549w, 531mb, 478m, 466m. Anal. Calc. for C68H76Mn6N12O24 (1775.05): C, 46.01; H, 4.32; N, 9.47. Found: C, 45.82; H, 4.35; N, 9.42%.

Single-crystal X-ray crystallography

A brown crystal of 2⋅2n(dmf) (0.05×0.15×0.19mm) was taken directly from the mother liquor and immediately cooled to -93°C. Diffraction measurements were made on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDER Image Plate diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu Kα radiation. Data collection (ω-scans) and processing (cell refinement, data reduction and Empirical absorption correction) were performed using the CrystalClear program package . The structure was solved by direct methods using Shelxs-97  and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 with Shelxl-97 . Important crystallographic data are listed in  . Further experimental crystallographic details for 2⋅2n(dmf): 2θ max =130°; reflections collected/unique/used, 17660/6037 [R int =0.0552]/6037; 509 parameters refined; (Δ/σ)max =0.001; (Δρ)max/(Δρ)min =0.610/-0.671e/Å3; R/R w (for all data), 0.0707/0.1581. Hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions as riding on bonded atoms. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The oxygen atom of the solvate dmf molecule was found disordered and was refined over two positions with occupation factors fixed at 0.50. Plots of the structures were drawn using the Diamond 3 program package .

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. For both complexes the <ce:italic>χT</ce:italic> is comparable with the theoretically expected value for six non-interacting <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 spins (18.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s. Below 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K a deviation from linearity is observed. This is often observed in SMMs and is attributed to the onset of quantum tunneling mechanisms for the relaxation.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic studies

DC magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out on polycrystalline samples of both 1 and 2 in the 2-300K range. The results are plotted in the form of χT versus T and are shown in  . The χT product of 1 at 300K is 18.4cm3 mol-1 K. This decreases upon cooling, reaching a value of 6.75cm3 mol-1 K at 2K. The χT product of 2 at 300K is 17.55cm3 mol-1 K. Upon cooling, χT decreases to a value of 11.78cm3 mol-1 K at 20K. Below 8.5K χT decreases abruptly reaching a value of 8.17cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0K. For both complexes the χT is comparable with the theoretically expected value for six non-interacting S =2 spins (18.00cm3 mol-1 K, g =2.0). The temperature dependence of χT suggests dominant antiferromagnetic intra-molecular interactions. The expected value for χT for an S =4 system is 10.0cm3 mol-1 K. The values of χT at 2K for 1 and 2 are smaller than this value and this could be due to zero field splitting effects and/or to the influence of low lying states. The magnetization isotherms for both complexes at 2K do not reach saturation up to a magnetic field of 8.5T indicating contributions from low lying excited states and/or intermolecular interactions.

In   we show the temperature dependency of α. For both complexes, α increases as the temperature decreases. This behavior is common in Single Molecule Magnets  as well as in other polynuclear transition metal clusters . For typical paramagnets α <0.3  and this is the case for 2 in the whole temperature range. For 1, however, α >0.45 reaching a value of 0.65 at the lowest temperature. Such large values are generally considered as an indication for spin glass behavior .

The temperature dependence of τ, in the form ln τ versus 1/T for both complexes is shown in  . For complex 1 a linear dependence is observed suggesting that relaxation follows an Arrhenius-type law, with the characteristic time τ at temperature T given by τ = τ 0⋅eΔ  E  /  kT . Fitting of the data yields a relaxation barrier ΔE of 23 (±2)K (16±1cm-1) with a pre-exponential factor τ 0 of 1.6 (±0.2)×10-8 s. For complex 2, a linear dependence is also observed for T >3.0K and fitting to the Arrhenius law yields ΔE =29 (±2)K (20±1cm-1) and τ 0 =2.7 (±0.2)×10-8 s. Below 3.0K a deviation from linearity is observed. This is often observed in SMMs and is attributed to the onset of quantum tunneling mechanisms for the relaxation.
